review.title: Modeling Suspicious Email Detection using Enhanced Feature Selection
review.abstract: The paper presents a suspicious email detection model which incorporates enhanced feature selection. In the paper we proposed the use of feature selection strategies along with classification technique for terrorists email detection. The presented model focuses on the evaluation of machine learning algorithms such as decision tree (ID3), logistic regression, Na\"ive Bayes (NB), and Support Vector Machine (SVM) for detecting emails containing suspicious content. In the literature, various algorithms achieved good accuracy for the desired task. However, the results achieved by those algorithms can be further improved by using appropriate feature selection mechanisms. We have identified the use of a specific feature selection scheme that improves the performance of the existing algorithms.

sections.heading: V. PROPOSED METHODOLOGY
sections.text: Our proposed methodology uses machine learning methods to detect suspicious e-mails. It evaluates the performance of four classifiers with feature selection strategies. The algorithm for the proposed methodology is in Fig. 1. The algorithm described in Fig. 1 illustrates how suspicious e-mail detection models work. sections.heading: A. Feature Selection
sections.text: Feature selection is a way to select a subset of the original feature space. The number of features in space influences the computation time and also the accuracy of the classifier. The key idea behind the feature selection is to search for a viable subset of features by evaluating them, by some evaluators [14]. In this essay, we focus on the correct feature selection, through which we could achieve a relatively better performance of the required task even with existing algorithms. Feature F is defined as a vector of K and I and it is the original feature space: F = {K1, K2,...... Kn, I1, I2,...... In} (1) K is a vector of n key words and I is a vector of indicators. Among the indicators, some indicators make the e-mail suspicious and some make the e-mail unsuspicious: I = Is + (2) Suspicious, "K is a function of n key words and I is a vector of Suspicious, and K is a vector of indicators.

sections.heading: B. System Architecture
sections.text: The strategy applied in the proposed system for selecting and generating features is that it is kept outside the main classification engine, which contains different classification algorithms. This means that the feature selection is applied before classification. We used the well-known open source data mining tool WEKA (Waikato Environment for Knowledge Analysis) [29] for our feature selection and classification purposes. First, a text message is given as input and then feature selection strategies are applied. The extracted features are recorded in the ARFF file format, which is the WEKA-specific form of a Comma Separated Values (CSV) file. WEKA expects the input file to be available in the ARFF format. Communication between WEKA and our proposed system is carried out using the data exchange. The original feature space is displayed separately by WEKA using a Rule Engine Execuwords manually, the corresponding feature selection method is applied in the corresponding WEKA filter and the corresponding feature method.

sections.heading: VI. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
sections.text: Our experiments were performed using the steps that were given in the algorithm in Fig. 57 For conducting the experiments as mentioned before we used WEKA Data Mining Tool. We have developed the terror email record from various sources such as news groups. We have also used some emails that are used by the authors [1]. Some other emails are also stupid emails. The reason for developing such a data set is that to the best of our knowledge there are no benchmark email records available in the field of counter-terrorism.

sections.heading: VII. CONCLUSION AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: In this paper, we have presented suspicious e-mail detection strategies that use different classification and selection methods. We concluded that in the specific task, the decision tree algorithm (ID3) outperformed the rest of the state of the art classifiers as Naïve Bayes, SVM and logistic regression. Once the appropriate selection strategy is applied, the logistic regression algorithm also achieves maximum performance in terms of accuracy. We also plan to apply the classification method for the specific task. We also plan to apply the selection method for suspicious e-mail detection task. Currently, the experiments are being conducted in relatively small datasets, but in the future, we plan to construct larger datasets from terrorist statements.
